entry.title: I think I might suck at blogging...
entry.content:
The Problem

I changed my theme recently. I actually changed my whole website. I was wrestling with some build issues in Hugo, so I switched to Zola. So far, so good.

In porting my old posts, I realised they were Very Poor Quality.

I was a bit disappointed to find out how much even I didn‚Äôt want to read these posts 6 months later. Clearly I needed to work on this if I was going to ramp it up again. So, like many of modern first-world problems, I took it to ChatGPT with a kind of hopeful curiousity it would give me a magic solution:

‚ÄúI‚Äôve tried to get into blogging, but whenever I start, the blog post gets way too big, the meaning gets mushy and even I wouldn‚Äôt want to read it. I‚Äôve got three or four so far and they‚Äôre all enormous and really boring.

They also take a huge amount of effort. And my post frequency has gone way down because of it. I guess that‚Äôs becayse I‚Äôve started dreading doing it.

I want my posts to be meaningful. First and foremost to me. I want my blogging to be an extension of my note taking, but be the really important or useful/thoughtful stuff that helps others, or stuff I really want to highlight to myself so I don‚Äôt forget.

How do I blog better?

Help me, Obi-Wan Kenobi. You‚Äôre my only hope.‚Äú

The Solution

Thus, the Oracle responded:

‚ÄúIt sounds like you‚Äôre caught in the common trap of over-ambition when blogging, where the desire for perfection or depth makes the process unwieldy and unenjoyable. Here‚Äôs a framework to help you blog better‚Äù

A Better Blogging Framework

It sounds like you‚Äôre caught in the common trap of over-ambition when blogging, where the desire for perfection or depth makes the process unwieldy and unenjoyable. Here‚Äôs a framework to help you blog better:

1. Redefine What ‚ÄúMeaningful‚Äù Means üí≠

  • A post doesn‚Äôt have to be exhaustive to be meaningful. Focus on one insight, idea, or question per post.
  • Your blog can serve as ‚Äúworking thoughts‚Äù rather than finished masterpieces. Treat it as an ongoing conversation with yourself and your readers.

Definitely struggled with this one. I would start a post, and then think ‚Äúwell, I should probably expand on this, or add this, or include that‚Ä¶‚Äù and then I‚Äôd end up with a massive post that didn‚Äôt really adhere to the idea I wanted to share. It would just become a preachy jumble of thoughts.

2. Start Small and Specific üìù

  • Break your ideas into smaller pieces. If your draft is massive, split it into a series of posts. For example:
    • Post 1: The problem or context.
    • Post 2: An insight or solution.
    • Post 3: Reflection or practical application.

Agree üëç I think if I can exercise #1 properly, I won‚Äôt actually need to do this often. Unless it‚Äôs a great topic worth a lot of conversation.

3. Write for Your Past Self üßí ‚¨ÖÔ∏è

  • Imagine you‚Äôre writing to help a version of yourself from 6-12 months ago. This will:
    • Sharpen your focus.
    • Keep the content relatable and actionable.

Interesting. I took the popularity of the Learning in Public movement as permission to write publicly as a non-expert, but I keep finding myself writing as if I am an expert. Maybe that‚Äôs an ego-check.

4. Use Templates to Structure Posts üìÑ

A template can help keep your writing concise and focused:

  1. Hook: Why this topic matters (1-2 sentences).
  2. Main Idea: What‚Äôs the core point you‚Äôre sharing?
  3. Supporting Points: 2-3 short paragraphs that back it up.
  4. Reflection or Call to Action: What‚Äôs the takeaway? How can this help others or yourself in the future?

I‚Äôve never done this. I‚Äôve always just written. I‚Äôll give it a shot.

5. Limit Writing Time ‚è∞

  • Set a timer for 30-60 minutes. Treat it as an experiment in speed and clarity.
  • Publish after one or two edits. Imperfect but consistent posts are better than perfect ones that never happen.

I really like this idea. I‚Äôve been getting into the Pomodoro Technique recently and I‚Äôm finding it really helps. This could be a healthy application of the same principles.

6. Treat Your Blog Like a Curation Space üìö

  • If a full blog post feels too heavy, share:
    • A key takeaway from a book or podcast.
    • A solution to a problem you solved at work.
    • A reflective ‚Äúaha moment‚Äù in a few paragraphs.
  • These smaller posts still add value and showcase your thinking.

Really good idea. I‚Äôve done that a little for social media (LinkedIn and Twitter) but I hadn‚Äôt practiced that with blogging.

7. Iterate and Expand Later

  • A blog post doesn‚Äôt have to be a final product. Treat it like a ‚Äúversion 1.0‚Äù that you can refine or expand over time.
  • Link posts together, turning smaller pieces into a cohesive body of work.

While I like the idea, I think I lack the discipline to practice it. I‚Äôve mentioned things I want to cover at the end of previous posts, and then never got back to them. Maybe I‚Äôd rework this as #2. If I think it needs to be expanded, I‚Äôll either make sure I‚Äôm really committed to finishing it or I‚Äôll draft the post and split it up once the whole series is finished.

8. Write What You‚Äôd Want to Read

  • Use bullet points, bold headings, and concise sentences. These make posts more readable and less intimidating to write.
  • Ask yourself: ‚ÄúIf I stumbled upon this, would I read it?‚Äù

Definitely have not been doing that. Clearly üòÇ

9. Use Feedback Loops

  • Share drafts with trusted peers or mentors for feedback. Their perspective can help you identify mushy sections.
  • Analytics can also reveal which posts resonate most.

üëç

10. Remember: Blogging Is Practice

Every post improves your ability to communicate ideas effectively. Even ‚Äúboring‚Äù or ‚Äúimperfect‚Äù ones are a step forward.

ü§ó

Next Steps

  1. Choose one of your massive drafts junky old posts. Extract a single idea and rewrite it using the template above.
  2. Publish it quickly. Don‚Äôt overthink it.
  3. Commit to a smaller post for your next one to build momentum.

By focusing on these practices, you‚Äôll find blogging more manageable and rewarding while steadily building a meaningful portfolio of posts that reflect your growth.

Final Thoughts

I doubt you‚Äôre reading this because you want my thoughts on blogging. If you wanted help with blogging, you could have asked ChatGPT yourself!

You know that. I know that. So why did I write this at all?

To keep me accountable.

I may not follow to the letter, but if it‚Äôs here amongst my other posts to keep me in check.
